III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Title Health services; policies and procedures.
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and
behavioral health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was not afforded proper medical attention after getting
injured playing basketball.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed on 03/20/2025 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She reported a knee injury she
experienced months prior to the allegations, resulting in a mild
strain. Youth A recalled playing basketball recently when she felt
like she hurt her knee again. That day Staff 1 called the facility’s
medical services phone line and was instructed to have Youth A
take ibuprofen and ice her knee. Youth A reported using ice for
her knee but declined taking any over-the-counter pain
medication. She stated that sometime later Youth A wrote a
medical complaint regarding her knee. The following day Nurse 1
visited Youth A’s unit to see another youth, but did not see
her. Youth A recalled Nurse 1 stating “I’m only here to see one
person.” Youth A recalled continuing to ice her knee until Nurse 1
came to see her the morning of this interview. Youth A was sent
out to have her knee examined that morning, but the visit was
unsuccessful due to complications regarding her insurance.
Chief Administrator was interviewed over the phone on
03/20/2025 and 05/01/2025. She recalled Youth A’s past knee
issues that began prior to her placement at the facility. Chief
Administrator did not have any concern over proper attention paid
to possible injuries to Youth A. Chief Administrator provided
further detail on the course of events after Youth A injured her
knee. The medical service line was contacted on the same day of
the injury, 03/14/2025, with recommendations that the youth could
be treated without leaving the facility. Youth A was taken to
urgent care on 03/20/2025 at Youth A’s request, but was unable to
be seen because of insurance issues. She returned to urgent
care for medical attention the following day on 03/21/2025, but
2

that was not because of her knee and was because of Youth A
punching a wall on 03/21/2025 and injuring her hand. Chief
Administrator confirmed Youth A had not been sent back out to
external medical professionals for her knee. She also stated the
medical service line was contacted on 03/25/2025 to further
assess Youth A’s knee, and the same recommendations of over-
the-counter treatments were provided.
Nurse 1 was interviewed over the phone on 04/25/2025. She
recalled the instance of Youth A playing basketball and hurting her
knee. She could not recall when she saw Youth A. Nurse 1
stated that, when she examined Youth A’s knee, it did not have
any swelling or bruising. She recalled advising Youth A to
continue to ice her knee, take over-the-counter pain medication
and try not to put too much weight on it if it was sore. Nurse 1
recalled Youth A being upset at these recommendations, and as a
result it was decided Youth A should have her knee examined
elsewhere.
Staff 1 was interviewed over the phone on 04/25/2025. He
recalled being present when Youth A was playing basketball when
she took a weird turn and stated that her knee hurt. He recalled
getting ice for her and calling the facility’s medical service phone
line. He was instructed to have her continue to ice her knee and
provide over-the-counter pain medication as needed. Staff 1
recalled working with Youth A in the following days and asking her
about her knee, with no concerns about worsening issues being
raised. Staff 1 did not believe it was strongly considered at that
time if Youth A should be taken to urgent care to have her knee
examined and was aware that nursing staff had seen her for her
knee since the basketball incident. He confirmed taking her to
urgent care on multiple other occasions for other concerns.
Documentation reviewed:
• Facility policy titled “Health and Dental” was provided and
reviewed. This policy stated, “The coordination of all
medical, dental, emergency and crisis related services are
conducted via arrangement with the following community
based resources/organizations,” with local hospitals listed
for emergency medical needs.
• “Behavior Notification” documentation from the facility
regarding Youth A and issues with her knee was provided
and reviewed.
o The first document dated 03/14/2025 described
Youth A playing basketball and hurting her
knee. The medical service phone line was
3

contacted and provided recommendations as
described in interviews for this investigation.
o Additional documentation dated 03/17/2025
described Youth A complaining of knee pain. Youth
A was provided over-the-counter medication.
• Documentation from the facility’s medical service phone
line dated 03/14/2025 was provided. This described the
phone contact from staff regarding Youth A’s knee and the
resulting recommendation of ice, rest and over-the-counter
medication to be provided to Youth A.
• A facility “Health Care Concern & Complaint Form” dated
03/17/2025 and authored by Youth A was provided and
reviewed. In it she described increased knee pain. The
“Evaluation & Treatment” section documented that Youth A
was sent to an urgent care to have her knee examined but
was unable to because of insurance issues. This was not
dated.
• Medical documentation regarding Youth A and other
medical concerns occurring at the same time as her knee
was provided and reviewed.
o Youth A was seen at the hospital on 03/21/2025 for
pain and bruising in her right hand after she punched
a wall and car door. No fracture was found, and
Youth A was discharged with pain medication
prescribed. Youth A did not disclose any pain in her
knee and her knee was not examined during this
appointment.
o The medical service phone line was contacted on
03/25/2025 for Youth A regarding her knee. It was
reported Youth A was experiencing knee pain, there
was no swelling, and she was able to put some
pressure on it. Icing, rest and over-the-counter
medication was recommended.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews and documentation reviewed Youth A was afforded
adequate health services after injuring her knee.
Technical Assistance
The facility was provided technical assistance in the area of
properly documenting all efforts to provide medical services to
youth.
In addition, the facility was provided with technical assistance in
the area of the provision of medical services. When youth have
issues with medical insurance that initially prevent medical
4

services from being provided, the facility is advised to have plans
and financial assistance readily available to ensure medical needs
are met timely. They can then work with appropriate parties for
possible reimbursement when necessary.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
